body.p: This document is intended to help System Administrators use and access systems in a safe and secure manner.
To help identify formal policy statements, each is prefixed with an identifier of the form: POLSYADxxx, where xxx is a unique ID number.
This policy applies to all system administrators working with systems.
All system administrators follow this policy.
System administrators also be compliant with the System Operating Procedures (SyOps) that apply for a given system they administer.
System Administrators read this document prior to using an system for the first time.
System Administrators revisit this document every six (6) months or so, to remind themselves of the content. Audits will check that the policy is being followed.

System Administrators are responsible for maintaining the security of systems. Failure to comply with this policy or the system SyOPs could lead to compromise of the 's infrastructure, or the services it uses or connects to. Failure to comply with this policy or corresponding SyOPs would be considered a breach of the IT Security Policy.
For any security related information or help, get in contact.

ul.li: Routine physical checks of server room be performed to identify unknown equipment and evidence of tampering.
A hardware asset register be kept and maintained by the system administrator to assist in equipment monitoring.
Any evidence of tampering be immediately reported to the Operational Security Team (OST): .
System administrator ensure an appropriate environment to protect system hardware, for example through air conditioning or dust prevention sheets.
Access to a server room be logged and monitored.
If an electronic monitoring system is not in place (such as key card entry), then a manual log of sever room activity be taken.
Accounts only be created when correct authorisation has been received.
Permissions granted to accounts be commensurate to the account's business role.
Accounts be enabled only when there is confirmation that a user understands and will comply with the system SyOps.
Account usage be reviewed on regular intervals.
If an account is dormant, the System Administrator investigate its status, and disable the account if appropriate.
When staff members leave the organisation or where the account is not required, the corresponding accounts be disabled.
Administrator level accounts only be used when carrying out administrative tasks.
For all non-administrative tasks, a normal (non-privileged) User account be used.
All changes to an System be approved and tested prior to implementation on the live system (e.g. in a Non-Live Environment).
System Administrators maintain an audit log of configuration changes and ensure that changes do not affect the secure operation of the IT system.
Changes be implemented unless the corresponding Operational Change Request (OCR) has been approved by IT Security.
Any change which affect the security posture or risk profile of the system be reported.
All system software be kept patched and up-to-date in accordance with the Patch Management Guide.
If one exists, a security patch first be tested in the non-live test environment.

The system administrator :
Verifying the origin and authenticity of the patch.
Checking the patch and its source media for viruses or malware.
Confirming the base environment required to apply the patch.
Finding out if there are common problems with applying the new patch of software.
Un-patched system software be identified and reported to the OST: .
Problems discovered in patch testing be documented and reported to the and system owner.
